question.text: Which of the following organisms is a retrovirus?

explanation.concept_text: Retroviruses are single-stranded RNA viruses that use an enzyme called reverse transcriptase to make a DNA complement of their RNA genome by hijacking the host cell’s replication machinery. This DNA complement is then used to synthesize mRNA or enter the lysogenic cycle in order to become incorporated into the host DNA. A common example of retrovirus is HIV. HIV is classified as a retrovirus because it carries RNA instead of DNA, along with reverse transcriptase, to infect host cells. Since retroviruses are single-stranded RNA viruses, Option B is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Double-stranded DNA virus – This option is incorrect because retroviruses are single-stranded RNA viruses, not double-stranded DNA viruses. Retroviruses and double-stranded DNA viruses replicate in different ways. Double-stranded DNA viruses replicate by first replicating DNA and forming new viral DNA, then transcribing the new viral DNA to produce viral proteins that combine with DNA to form new viruses. Option C. Archaebacteria – This option is incorrect because archaebacteria are NOT viruses. While archaebacteria are living cells that can survive inside or outside a host, viruses lack independent metabolism and, therefore, are not considered truly “alive.” Archaebacteria are non-pathogenic prokaryotes that differ from regular bacteria. For example, archaea cell walls contain various polysaccharides, whereas bacterial cell walls contain peptidoglycan. Option D. Shark – This option is incorrect because sharks are eukaryotes and eukaryotes are NOT viruses. Eukaryotes are organisms whose cells contain a nucleus and other membrane-bound organelles. Viruses can neither be classified as prokaryotic nor eukaryotic as they are not made up of cells. Sharks, in particular, are vertebrate chordates: animals that have vertebrae that enclose the spinal cord. Option E. Lichen – This option is incorrect because lichens are classified as fungi and fungi are NOT viruses. While fungi are eukaryotic, viruses can neither be classified as prokaryotic nor eukaryotic as they are not made up of cells. Lichens, specifically, are symbiotic associations between fungi and algae or cyanobacteria. The fungi receive carbohydrates produced by algae or cyanobacteria via photosynthesis. The fungi, in return, provides nitrogen, water, protection from the environment (for example, toxic chemicals to protect against grazers), and/or UV light.

question.text: There is a genetic disorder that leads to deteriorated vision in men or women which is sex-linked. It can lead to partial or complete blindness. Which chromosome could this gene be found on?

explanation.concept_text: Genetic disorders can either be autosomal or sex-linked. If a genetic disorder is autosomal , it is associated with an autosome (one of the numbered chromosomes). Humans have 22 pairs of autosomes. If a genetic disorder is sex-linked , it is associated with either the X chromosome or the Y chromosome. If a genetic disorder is Y-linked , all males with the disease-associated allele will be affected, since males only have one Y chromosome. (Males have XY chromosomes, indicating one X chromosome and one Y chromosome.) On the other hand, females cannot be affected by a Y-linked disorder, since females don’t have a Y chromosome. (Females have XX chromosomes, indicating two X chromosomes.) If a genetic disorder is X-linked , all males with the disease-associated allele will be affected, since males only have one X chromosome. Females with one disease-associated X allele and one unaffected X allele is a carrier . Carriers can display either partial or no symptoms. On the other hand, females with two disease-associated X alleles will be fully affected. Since the question indicates that the genetic disorder can affect both men and women, we can infer that the genetic disorder is X-linked because women cannot be affected by Y-linked disorders. Furthermore, the question indicates that the genetic disorder can lead to complete or partial blindness. Since partial symptoms can only occur when females have one disease-associated X allele and one unaffected X allele, we can once again infer that the disorder must be X-linked. Therefore, Option D is correct. Note: The genetic disorder described in this question is X-linked retinoschisis. X-linked retinoschisis is a genetic disorder causing the loss of central and peripheral vision due to degradation of the retina. Since X-linked retinoschisis is a X-linked genetic disorder, the gene causing the disease can be found on the X chromosome
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Chromosome 21 – This option is incorrect because the genetic disorder is known to be sex-linked, while Chromosome 21 is NOT a sex chromosome. Chromosome 21, in fact, is associated with Down’s Syndrome. Down’s Syndrome is caused when there is an extra copy of Chromosome 21. Option B. Chromosome 15 – This option is incorrect because the genetic disorder is known to be sex-linked, while Chromosome 15 is NOT a sex chromosome. Option C. Any autosomal chromosome – This option is incorrect because the genetic disorder is known to be sex-linked. Hence, the gene causing the genetic disorder cannot be found on an autosomal chromosome. Option E. Y chromosome – This option is incorrect because the genetic disorder affects both men and women. Since women do not have a Y chromosome, they cannot be affected by a Y-linked genetic disorder. Furthermore, since the genetic disorder can lead to complete or partial blindness, it must be X-linked because partial symptoms can only occur when females have one disease-associated X allele and one unaffected allele.

question.text: A botanist has discovered a new plant and notes that it is predominantly found in its gametophyte form. Which category does this plant most likely belong to?

explanation.concept_text: All land plants undergo reproduction with an alternation of generations scheme (shown below) which alternates between diploid (2n) and haploid (n) reproduction stages. However, plants differ in their most prominent phase. While the tracheophytes (including seedless tracheophytes, seeded angiosperms, and gymnosperms) are found most prominently in the diploid sporophyte phase, bryophytes are found most prominently in their gametophyte phase. Therefore, Option A is correct. This dominance of the gametophyte phase and the lack of true vasculature characterize the bryophytes . CC BY 3.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Angiosperm – This option is incorrect because angiosperms are found most prominently in the diploid sporophyte phase. Unlike bryophytes, angiosperms have vascular structures, and it should be noted that plants that have a dominant gametophyte generation will lack true vascular structure. Angiosperms (fruits, maple, oaks, grass, etc) are flowering plants and are the dominant land plant form. The flower is the reproductive structure of an angiosperm. Option C. Gymnosperm – This option is incorrect because gymnosperms are found most prominently in the diploid sporophyte phase. Unlike bryophytes, gymnosperms have vascular structures, and it should be noted that plants that have a dominant gametophyte generation will lack true vascular structure. Gymnosperms (pines, firs, spruces, junipers, redwoods, cedars, etc) are cone-bearing plants. They have pollen-bearing male cones and ovule-bearing female cones. Option D. Seedless Tracheophyte – This option is incorrect because seedless tracheophytes are found most prominently in the diploid sporophyte phase. Unlke bryophytes, seedless tracheophytes have vascular structures, and it should be noted that plants that have a dominant gametophyte generation will lack true vascular structure. Seedless tracheophytes (clubmosses, spike mosses, quillworts, ferns, horsetails, whisk ferns, etc) have true roots, leaves, and stems, but lack seeds. Option E. Endosperm – This option is incorrect because the endosperm is not a plant, but rather a specific type of supportive tissue that provides nutrition to the developing embryo. The endosperm can be found in the seed of the plant along with the embryo and the seed coat. In many monocots, the endosperm is the primary storage tissue, and the cotyledons transfer nutrients from the endosperm to the embryo. The endosperm is formed when the second sperm cell of the pollen tube fuses with the polar nuclei.

question.text: In the fetal circulatory system, the ductus venosus allows blood to bypass which of the following?

explanation.concept_text: As oxygenated and nutrient-rich blood from the placenta returns to the fetus via the umbilical vein, half of the blood enters the ductus venosus . The ductus venosus allows blood to bypass the liver as it returns to the heart. Blood bypasses the liver during fetal circulation because the liver in adults acts to filter and detoxify blood but is not fully functional during early development. The other half of the blood that didn‘t enter the ductus venosus enters the liver/portal vein. Since the ductus venosus allows blood to bypass the liver during fetal circulation, Option D is correct. The image below illustrates the main components of the fetal circulatory system, including the ductus venosus. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Pulmonary circulation – This option is incorrect because it is the foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus that allow pulmonary circulation to be bypassed. The foramen ovale is a small opening in the heart that allows blood to bypass pulmonary circulation by entering the left atrium directly from the right atrium, since there is no gas exchange in the fetal lung. The ductus arteriosus is a short vessel that conducts blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta, allowing it to bypass the lungs. Option B. Systemic circulation – This option is incorrect because the ductus venosus does NOT allow blood to bypass systemic circulation. Systemic circulation is a circulation pathway that allows blood to go to all body tissues. Option C. Placenta – This option is incorrect because the ductus venosus does NOT allow blood to bypass the placenta. Blood, in fact, must return to the placenta in order to obtain oxygen and nutrients from the maternal blood supply. Once the oxygenated, nutrient-rich blood from the placenta is carried to the fetus, half of this blood enters the ductus venosus which allows blood to bypass the liver. Option E. Right ventricle – This option is incorrect because the ductus venosus does NOT allow blood to bypass the right ventricle; it is the foramen ovale that allows blood to bypass the right ventricle. The foramen ovale is a small opening in the heart that allows blood to bypass the right ventricle by entering the left atrium directly from the right atrium.

question.text: Which of the following would be the most immediate consequence of a defective sperm without an acrosome reaching the egg for fertilization?

options.label: C.
options.text: Prevent the movement of sperm through follicular cells

options.label: D.
options.text: Prevent fusion of sperm with zona pellucida

explanation.concept_text: Sperm (male sex cells) are made up of the head, mid-piece, and tail. The head of the sperm contains the acrosome, a lysosome-like organelle containing hydrolytic enzymes that allow sperm to digest through the zona pellucida to get to the oocyte. The zona pellucida is an external glycoprotein membrane surrounding the plasma membrane of an oocyte. Once sperm comes into contact with the zona pellucida, the zona pellucida expresses specific receptor proteins called ZP3 which bind to proteins expressed in the head of the sperm. Such binding of ZP3 triggers the acrosome reaction during which the acrosomal enzymes are released. These enzymes digest a path through the zona pellucida, allowing the sperm to enter the perivitelline space and ultimately fuse with the plasma membrane of the oocyte. Therefore, the absence of an acrosome would prevent sperm from penetrating the zona pellucida in order to reach the oocyte, fuse cell bodies, and share its genetic material in the process of fertilization. Since the inability to penetrate the zona pellucida is an immediate consequence of a defective sperm without an acrosome, Option E is correct. CC BY 4.0 CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. ATP depletion – This option is incorrect because the production of ATP is carried out by the mitochondria within the mid-piece of sperm. The midpiece of sperm contains the flagellum and lots of mitochondria. Hence, the absence of an acrosome will not have an effect on the sperm’s ATP. Option B. Complete immobility – This option is incorrect because movement is facilitated by the tail of the sperm, which is energized by the ATP made by the mitochondria in the mid-piece. The whiplike motion of the tail and mid-piece propels the sperm to move forward. Therefore, a mutation within the acrosome vesicle of sperm would not impact its mobility. Option C. Prevent the movement of sperm through follicular cells – This option is incorrect because the follicular cells are contained within the corona radiata layer of the oocyte, the penetration of which is not dependent on acrosomal enzymes. The corona radiata is a dense layer of granulosa cells surrounding the oocyte. The zona pellucida, instead, is the layer of the oocyte that is degraded by the acrosomal enzymes in order for sperm to reach the oocyte. Option D. Prevent fusion of sperm with zona pellucida – This option is incorrect because the acrosome is tasked with helping to penetrate past the zona pellucida, not fusing the sperm with it. The sperm fuses directly with the oocyte membrane instead after penetrating the zona pellucida.

question.text: All of the following are characteristics of IgG antibodies EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: Has two heavy and two light chains

options.label: B.
options.text: Heavy and light chains connected via disulfide bonds

options.label: C.
options.text: Involved in passive immunity of fetus

explanation.concept_text: When B cells are activated in response to antigens, they produce antibodies. Antibodies are defensive immune proteins that are specific to each antigen. These Y-shaped proteins consist of constant and variable regions as well as two heavy and two light chains. Antibodies also have disulfide bonds that connect heavy chains to each other and to light chains. The structure of antibodies is shown below. CC BY 4.0 Antibodies have 5 classes: IgA, IgD, IgE, IgG, IgM. IgG antibodies, specifically, are the most abundant antibodies in serum and extravascular spaces. These antibodies can cross the placenta and are most important in protecting the fetus from foreign antigens. Since a pentameric structure is unique to IgM (IgG has a monomeric structure instead), Option E is correct. The roles of the five major immunoglobulins are summarized in the table below. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Has two heavy and two light chains – This option is incorrect because all classes of antibodies contain two heavy and two light chains. Since IgG is a type of antibody, IgG also has two heavy and two light chains. Option B. Heavy and light chains connected via disulfide bonds – This option is incorrect because each light chain of an immunoglobulin is linked to a heavy chain with disulfide bonds, regardless of the type of antibody. The two heavy chains are also joined by disulfide bonds. These disulfide bonds are characteristic of the immunoglobulin structure and should be recognized for the exam. Option C. Involved in passive immunity of fetus – This option is incorrect because due to its compact monomeric structure, IgG can cross the placenta and provide the developing fetus with passive immunity. The protection of the fetus by the mother’s IgG antibodies is considered passive immunity because the antibodies in the recipient (fetus) are produced by another individual (mother). Option D. Participates in opsonization – This option is incorrect because as with components of the complement system, IgG can surround pathogens and mark them for digestion by phagocytes in a process known as opsonization. The phagocytosis of antigens can be carried out by macrophages, neutrophils, or natural killer cells.

question.text: What is the effect of progesterone at its peak?

explanation.concept_text: The menstrual cycle of the female reproductive cycle begins with the initiation of the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary. Low levels of estrogen and progesterone stimulate the hypothalamus, causing it to secrete GnRH. GnRH then stimulates the anterior pituitary to release FSH and LH. The produced FSH stimulates the follicles to secrete estrogen. The increase in estrogen causes positive feedback on the hypothalamus, prompting it to produce more GnRH. The anterior pituitary then produces large amounts of LH. The surge of LH triggers ovulation, secreting estrogen and progesterone. The increase in estrogen and progesterone stimulates the thickening of the endometrium in preparation for implantation of the fertilized egg. Since high levels of progesterone cause the endometrial wall to thicken, Option E is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Ovulation – This option is incorrect because ovulation is NOT caused by high levels of progesterone; it is instead caused by a surge in LH. During ovulation, the ovary releases a secondary oocyte from its vesicular follicle. The secondary oocyte then enters and moves along the fallopian tube (oviduct). Option B. Triggers an LH surge – This option is incorrect because an LH surge is NOT caused by high levels of progesterone. When FSH stimulates follicles to secrete estrogen, the increased levels of estrogen triggers the hypothalamus to produce GnRH. The GnRH then causes the anterior pituitary to produce a surge of LH. The LH surge triggers ovulation, a process in which an egg is released from an ovary. Option C. Fertilization – This option is incorrect because fertilization is NOT caused by high levels of progesterone. Fertilization occurs when sperm penetrates the plasma membrane of a secondary oocyte. This process, however, cannot occur until capacitation and acrosomal reaction have taken place. During capacitation, the plasma membrane surrounding the head of the sperm is destabilized, allowing the sperm to become hyperactive. Once the sperm comes into contact with the zona pellucida of the oocyte, the receptor proteins (ZP3) of the zona pellucida bind to proteins in the head of the sperm. This binding triggers the acrosomal reaction in which the enzymatic contents of the acrosome are released. Option D. Lactation – This option is incorrect because lactation is NOT caused by high levels of progesterone. Prolactin and oxytocin are hormones associated with lactation. During lactation, prolactin promotes the production of milk and oxytocin promotes the ejection of milk. Hence, the effects of these hormones allow mothers to feed their babies and supply them with nutrients and antibodies essential for survival.

question.text: Which of the following describes how the endometrium is maintained after implantation?

options.label: A.
options.text: Estrogen and progesterone levels are suppressed

explanation.concept_text: Once implantation occurs, the placenta starts secreting human chorionic gonadotrophin (hCG) which maintains the corpus luteum. The corpus luteum secretes estrogen and progesterone. Normally, when implantation does not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates and as estrogen and progesterone levels drop, the endometrium is shed as menstrual flow. However, to allow pregnancy to continue, the hCG secreted by the placenta allows the endometrium to be maintained. The image below provides a walkthrough of the ovarian and menstrual cycles and the hormone changes throughout. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Estrogen and progesterone levels are suppressed – This option is incorrect because estrogen and progesterone are needed to maintain the endometrium, therefore they are not suppressed. Option C. Corpus luteum disintegrates – This option is incorrect because the corpus luteum must be maintained, as it secretes estrogen and progesterone which will then go on to maintain the endometrium after implantation. Option D. FSH levels spike – This option is incorrect because FSH does not spike to maintain the endometrium. The elevation in FSH is what allows for the recruitment of a cohort of ovarian follicles in each ovary. Option E. LH levels spike– This option is incorrect because an LH spike is required for ovulation. There is no LH spike after the implantation of a blastocyst or the maintenance of the endometrium after implantation.

question.text: The below embryo (cross-sectioned) is undergoing gastrulation. Which layer will form the musculoskeletal system?

explanation.concept_text: The formation of the gastrula occurs with the invagination of a group of cells into the blastula, forming a double-layered embryo with an opening from the outside into a center cavity. The gastrula contains three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. The ectoderm is the outermost layer, the mesoderm is the middle layer, and the endoderm is the innermost layer. The three germ layers give rise to all subsequent tissues. The ectoderm gives rise to the nervous system (brain, spinal cord), integument (epidermis, hair, epithelium of nose, mouth, anal canal), sensory structures (lens and retina of eye), neural tube, teeth/jaws/bones of face/skull, and adrenal medulla. The mesoderm gives rise to the musculoskeletal system, circulatory/lymphatic system, excretory system, gonads, connective tissue, portions of digestive/respiratory system, notochord, somites, kidney, dermis of skin, and adrenal cortex. The endoderm gives rise to the epithelial lining of the digestive/respiratory tract, parts of the liver, pancreas, gall bladder, thyroid and parathyroid, thymus, and urinary bladder lining. In the image, the blue layer is the outermost layer (ectoderm), the green layer is the middle layer (mesoderm), and the red layer is the innermost layer (endoderm). The hollow area of the image is the central cavity of the gastrula that later forms the digestive tract. Since the mesoderm gives rise to the musculoskeletal system and the mesoderm is in the middle of the three germ layers, Option C is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Layer A – This option is incorrect because Layer A refers to the endoderm and the endoderm does NOT give rise to the musculoskeletal system. The endoderm gives rise to the epithelial lining of the digestive/respiratory tract, parts of the liver, pancreas, gall bladder, thyroid and parathyroid, thymus, and urinary bladder lining. Option B. Layer B – This option is incorrect because Layer B refers to the ectoderm and the ectoderm does NOT give rise to the musculoskeletal system. The ectoderm gives rise to the nervous system (brain, spinal cord), integument (epidermis, hair, epithelium of nose, mouth, anal canal), sensory structures (lens and retina of eye), neural tube, teeth/jaws/bones of face/skull, and adrenal medulla. Option D. Hollow area D – This option is incorrect because Hollow area D refers to the blastocoel which is the central cavity of the gastrula that later forms the digestive tract as it connects the mouth and anus to form a one-way digestive path. The central cavity of the gastrula does NOT give rise to any tissue; hence, it cannot form the musculoskeletal system.

question.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding regulation of the Lac operon?

options.label: A.
options.text: When allolactose is present, it binds to and activates an activator protein

options.label: B.
options.text: When allolactose is present, it binds to and deactivates an activator protein

options.label: C.
options.text: When allolactose is present, it binds to and deactivates a repressor protein

options.label: D.
options.text: When allolactose is present, it binds to and activates a repressor protein

options.label: E.
options.text: Allolactose is not involved in regulation of the Lac operon

correct_answer_text: When allolactose is present, it binds to and deactivates a repressor protein

explanation.concept_text: Operons are regions of DNA that control gene transcription. An operon consists of a set of structural and regulatory genes controlled by a promoter and an operator . This is an important concept to know for the test. The Lac operon in E. coli controls the breakdown of lactose. Three structural genes, lac Z, Y, and A, code for enzymes involved in lactose digestion. A regulatory gene produces an active repressor that binds to the operator and blocks RNA polymerase. When lactose is available, lacZ turns lactose into allolactose, which binds to the repressor and inactivates it, allowing RNA polymerase to attach and transcribe the genes. (Allolactose is a disaccharide that is an analogue of lactose; hence, lactose and allolactose can be used interchangeably in the context of the Lac operon.) Thus, enzymes for lactose breakdown are only produced when lactose is actually available. The image below provides a walkthrough of the Lac operon. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. When allolactose is present, it binds to and activates an activator protein – This option is incorrect because the Lac operon involves a repressor protein, not an activator. A regulatory gene of the Lac operon produces an active repressor that binds to the operator and blocks RNA polymerase. Allolactose, in fact, binds to and deactivates a repressor protein instead of an activator protein. Option B. When allolactose is present, it binds to and deactivates an activator protein – This option is incorrect because the Lac operon involves a repressor protein, not an activator. A regulatory gene of the Lac operon produces an active repressor that binds to the operator and blocks RNA polymerase. Allolactose, in fact, binds to and deactivates a repressor protein instead of an activator protein. This described scenario would also mean that the enzymes for lactose digestion are not produced when lactose is available to use. In reality, the enzymes for lactose digestion are only produced when lactose is available. Option D. When allolactose is present, it binds to and activates a repressor protein – This option is incorrect because the repressor is active in the absence of allolactose , ensuring the enzymes are produced when needed. Allolactose, in fact, binds to and deactivates the repressor protein of the Lac operon, blocking RNA polymerase. Option E. Allolactose is not involved in regulation of the Lac operon – This option is incorrect because allolactose controls the repressor protein of the Lac operon. Allolactose, in fact, binds to and deactivates the repressor protein of the Lac operon, blocking RNA polymerase.

question.text: Plants get their energy during daytime through photosynthesis. How do they keep producing energy and maintain themselves at night time?

options.label: A.
options.text: Photosynthesis can use moonlight with lower efficiency

options.label: B.
options.text: Plants have built-up starch stored that they use for energy during night time

options.label: C.
options.text: The Calvin Cycle shuts off during sunlight but turns on in its absence

options.label: D.
options.text: Plants shut off cellular function during night time

options.label: E.
options.text: Transpiration pulls up ATP from the soil for plants to use

correct_answer_text: Plants have built-up starch stored that they use for energy during night time

explanation.concept_text: During the day when sunlight is abundant, plants are able to perform the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis. The products of the light-dependent reactions (NAPDH and ATP) are then used to drive the dark reactions of photosynthesis, producing glucose. This glucose is used by the plant cell in aerobic respiration as a source of energy. However, in the absence of direct sunlight, the plant must be able to continue to sustain itself by using a stored energy source. Starch , a polymer of alpha-glucose molecules, functions as an energy storage in plant cells. Similar to how humans store excess glucose after a meal in the form of glycogen and break down the stored glycogen for glucose as needed, plant cells store excess glucose made during the day as starch. Plant cells store starch in storage vacuoles and plastids, specifically leucoplasts. Since plants cannot effectively perform photosynthesis during the night, they use built-up starch as an energy source; therefore, Option B is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Photosynthesis can use moonlight with lower efficiency – This option is incorrect because moonlight does not carry enough energy to excite electrons. In other words, plants cannot use moonlight to carry out photosynthesis. The light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis are initiated by the light energy from the sun exciting the trapped electrons of photosystem II. The light energy from the sun is once again used to reenergize electrons in photosystem I. Option C. T he Calvin Cycle shuts off during sunlight but turns on in its absence – This option is incorrect because although the Calvin Cycle does not directly use sunlight, the Calvin Cycle is most active during the day, after the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis have produced enough NADPH and ATP. Without the NADPH and ATP from the light-dependent reactions, the “dark reactions” of photosynthesis are unable to occur to any significant extent, despite their name. Option D. Plants shut off cellular function during night time – This option is incorrect because plants continue to carry out cellular function during the night. If a plant completely shuts off cellular function at night, then the plant will not be able to survive as it will not be performing cellular respiration. Remember that a plant performs a number of cellular activities to maintain itself – not just photosynthesis – and these processes need to occur regardless of the time of day. Option E. Transpiration pulls up ATP from the soil for plants to use – This option is incorrect because transpiration does NOT pull up ATP from the soil for plants to use. In fact, plants do not obtain ATP from the soil; plants produce their own ATP through photophosphorylation. Transpiration, instead, pulls up water from the soil for plants to use. When water transpires out of a plant, a suction force is created in the xylem which causes water to be pulled up from the roots to the stem and leaves.

question.text: Which of the following does alternative splicing allow for?

options.label: B.
options.text: Creation of multiple different proteins from one RNA strand

options.label: D.
options.text: Deletion of promoter regions unused in the final protein

options.label: E.
options.text: Combination of intron segments to create varying proteins

correct_answer_text: Creation of multiple different proteins from one RNA strand

explanation.concept_text: Alternative splicing allows for different segments of the RNA transcript to be selected as exons. Exons are the “expressed” sequences of DNA/RNA transcripts, while introns are the “interrupting” sequences of DNA/RNA transcripts. When exons are selected, introns are removed by the spliceosome. As a result, different mRNA can be generated from the same RNA transcript by selectively removing different parts of a RNA transcript to create different combinations. The ability to alternatively splice RNA allows for the creation of multiple different proteins from one RNA strand. For example, in the figure below, pre-mRNA can be spliced in three different ways, resulting in three different proteins. Alternative splicing is only seen in eukaryotes, and allows them to express a diversity of proteins beyond what their number of genes would indicate, since a single gene can be used to create many different proteins. Since alternative splicing allows for the creation of multiple different proteins from one RNA strand, Option B is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Removal of mutated gene segments – This option is incorrect because the removal of mutated gene segments is a repair mechanism, not a function of alternative splicing. Instead of removing mutated gene segments, alternative splicing removes introns when selecting exons to be part of the mRNA transcript. Option C. Longer proteins with enhanced function – This option is incorrect because alternative splicing does not necessarily allow for the creation of longer proteins with enhanced functions. Instead, alternative splicing allows for the creation of multiple different proteins. Option D. Deletion of promoter regions unused in the final protein – This option is incorrect because promoter regions are present on DNA strands, since promoter regions are where RNA polymerase attaches to begin transcription. The promoter region is upstream of the transcription start site and is not found on the resulting RNA strand (it does not get transcribed). Hence, there is no need for spliceosomes to delete promoter regions during alternative splicing because these regions simply do not exist on pre-mRNA. Option E. Combination of intron segments to create varying proteins – This option is incorrect because splicing causes intron segments to be removed, not combined, from the pre-mRNA to create varying proteins. Spliceosomes, specifically, remove introns from pre-mRNA. Splicing only selects exons to be part of the mRNA transcript.

question.text: A woman using human chorionic gonadotropin during fertility treatment would expect to see stimulated production of which hormone as a direct result?

explanation.concept_text: A woman undergoing fertility treatment would expect to see increased production of estrogen and progesterone from using human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). If implantation occurs under normal physiological conditions, the placenta will secrete hCG in order to maintain the corpus luteum. The corpus luteum is a mass of cells that forms in an ovary during every menstrual cycle. In turn, the corpus luteum continues to secrete estrogen and progesterone to maintain the endometrium for continued support of the developing embryo. If hCG is not present at the beginning of pregnancy, menstruation will begin and the embryo will abort because the endometrium will shed. After some time during pregnancy, hCG is replaced with direct progesterone production from the placenta. The image below shows the concentrations of various hormones throughout pregnancy. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. LH – This option is incorrect because luteinizing hormone (LH) production would not be increased following fertility treatment with hCG. LH production is increased when the anterior pituitary is stimulated by the production of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) from the hypothalamus. A surge in LH during the menstrual cycle triggers ovulation. During ovulation, a secondary oocyte is released from a vesicular follicle which can then be fertilized by a sperm. Option B. TSH – This option is incorrect because thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) production would not be increased following fertility treatment with hCG. TSH production is increased when the anterior pituitary is stimulated by the production of thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus. TSH, in fact, is completely uninvolved in reproduction. It instead functions to control the metabolism of the body. TSH stimulates the thyroid gland and causes it to increase in size and cell number. TSH also increases the rate of secretion of hormones T 3 (thyroxine) and T 4 (triiodothyronine). Option C. Oxytocin – This option is incorrect because oxytocin production would not be increased following fertility treatment with hCG. Oxytocin production is stimulated by uterine contractions during childbirth as well as contractions of the mammary glands during breastfeeding. As a result, oxytocin helps increase the strength of uterine contractions and milk ejection. Oxytocin also plays a role in facilitating maternal behavior and mother-infant bonding. Option E. Testosterone – This option is incorrect because testosterone production would not be increased following fertility treatment with hCG. Testosterone is a male sex hormone that is produced by Leydig cells of testes at the beginning of puberty. Male sex hormones, including testosterone, are secreted in the presence of LH. Testosterone, along with other hormones produced by reproductive organs, is a steroid hormone derived from cholesterol.

question.text: An archipelago is a group of islands. Which island would be expected to have the most species richness?

explanation.concept_text: Species diversity is the overall variety of different kinds of organisms in a community and consists of two components: species richness and relative abundance. Species richness represents the diversity of a community by describing the total number of different species present. Relative abundance reflects the amount of individuals in each species. Species richness on islands depends on island size and distance from the mainland . Species richness is directly proportional to a community’s geographic size. An increase in the area of a community leads to an increase in its diversity of habitats, resulting in an increase in the number of species. This concept is not restricted to only islands: generally speaking, the larger an area of environment that is present, the more species richness that would be observed. Furthermore, species richness is expected to decrease as an island’s distance from the mainland increases. If an island is far from the mainland, it has greater local extinctions and less immigration, causing a decrease in species richness. On the other hand, if an island is close to the mainland, the island will experience high levels of immigration, allowing more new species to be introduced to the community. We do not know the islands’ distance from the mainland for most of the options of this question; hence, we only need to take island size into account when ranking the islands’ species richness. Since species richness increases when a community’s geographic size increases, Option A is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Most isolated island – This option is incorrect because the most isolated island will have an extremely low species richness, regardless of its size. If an island is isolated from other communities, particularly the mainland, it will experience greater local extinctions and less immigration, resulting in a decrease in species richness. Option C. Oldest island  – This option is incorrect because the age of an island does not affect its species richness. Since we do not know the size of the island nor its distance from the mainland, we cannot determine its species richness. Option D. Island closest to another island – This option is incorrect because the proximity of an island to other islands is not the primary factor that affects species richness. An island's distance from the mainland, in fact, is a factor that affects species richness. Species richness declines as an island’s distance from the mainland increases. Option E. Tallest island – This option is incorrect because the height of an island does not affect its species richness. Island size is a factor that affects species richness on islands and it refers to the geographic area of the island, rather than height.

question.text: Which hormone is secreted from the same organ that it targets?

explanation.concept_text: During digestion, G cells of the stomach secrete gastrin , a large peptide hormone which is absorbed into blood. Gastrin then stimulates parietal cells of the stomach to secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl). The stomach is kept extremely acidic (pH of 2) in order to kill ingested bacteria and provide an optimal pH for pepsin, a digestive enzyme that degrades proteins into polypeptides. The release of HCl from parietal cells helps maintain the acidic environment of the stomach. Pepsin is originally secreted as pepsinogen from chief cells; however, HCl released by parietal cells helps to cleave pepsinogen into its active form of pepsin. Once the enzyme is activated, it can begin protein digestion. HCl also assists the absorption of vitamin B-12 in the ileum. Gastrin is a digestive hormone that is secreted from G cells in order to stimulate the HCl production of parietal cells. Since G cells and parietal cells are both located in the stomach, gastrin is a hormone that is secreted from the same organ that it targets. Therefore, Option D is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. T3 – This option is incorrect because while T3 is secreted from the thyroid gland, it targets the general body. In other words, T3 does not target a specific organ (or the thyroid gland itself). T3 is necessary for growth and neurological development in children. It also helps increase cellular metabolism (measured as the basal metabolic rate) of the body. Option B. Insulin – This option is incorrect because while insulin is secreted from the beta cells of the pancreas, it targets the liver, muscle cells, and fat tissues. Insulin stimulates these tissues to absorb glucose in order to lower blood glucose levels. Insulin does not target the pancreas itself. Insulin and glucagon are the two major peptide hormones involved in blood sugar regulation. Option C. Epinephrine – This option is incorrect because while epinephrine is secreted from the adrenal medulla, it targets many other tissues in the body rather than the adrenal medulla itself. Epinephrine stimulates the sympathetic nervous system and causes a “fight or flight” response, including the increase of blood glucose, blood pressure, and heartbeat.  While epinephrine increases blood flow to skeletal muscles, dilates the pupils, and increases the heart rate, it decreases blood flow to organs that are less relevant during a fight or flight situation, such as the intestines, bladder, etc. Epinephrine also increases metabolic activities and causes bronchodilation: the relaxation of smooth muscles in the airways. Option E. LH – This option is incorrect because while LH is secreted from the anterior pituitary, it targets the ovaries and testes. In females, LH stimulates the formation of the corpus luteum. A surge in LH can also trigger ovulation. Ovulation is a process in which a vesicular follicle of an ovary releases a secondary oocyte that can be fertilized by a sperm. In males, LH stimulates the Leydig cells of testes to produce testosterone.

question.text: In which of the following groups of organisms can simultaneous transcription and translation be observed?

explanation.concept_text: Prokaryotes lack membrane-bound organelles. They do, however, have an area of densely packed genetic material known as the nucleoid. Since prokaryotes lack a nuclear membrane that separates the genetic material from the rest of the cytoplasm, simultaneous transcription and translation may occur as shown in the image below. As soon as RNA polymerase produces an mRNA from the DNA during transcription, ribosomes can immediately access this mRNA for translation into proteins. In contrast, eukaryotes have their genome isolated in the nucleus. Hence, once RNA is transcribed from DNA, it must be exported out of the nucleus to the cytoplasm in order for the ribosomes to carry out translation. Since archaebacteria is classified as a prokaryote and none of the other options belongs to the prokaryotic kingdom, Option E is correct. CC BY 4.0 Process of Elimination Option A. Fungi – This option is incorrect because fungi are eukaryotes with genetic material sequestered in a nucleus. Since the genetic material of fungi is separated from the rest of the cell via a nuclear membrane, simultaneous transcription and translation cannot occur. While not all fungi are multicellular, all fungi are eukaryotic heterotrophs that grow as filaments called hyphae and can reproduce sexually or asexually. Fungi are generally responsible for decomposition of biological waste. Option B. Eukaryota – This option is incorrect because eukaryotes have genetic material sequestered in a nucleus. Since the genetic material of eukaryotes is separated from the rest of the cell via a nuclear membrane, simultaneous transcription and translation cannot occur. Instead, RNA must be exported out of the nucleus and into the cytoplasm for ribosomes to begin the process of translation. Option C. Protista – This option is incorrect because protists are eukaryotes with genetic material sequestered in a nucleus. Since the genetic material of protists is separated from the rest of the cell via a nuclear membrane, simultaneous transcription and translation cannot occur. Protista is an artificial kingdom classified by their means of obtaining nutrition. Algae are plant-like protists that obtain energy by photosynthesis. Protozoa are animal-like protists that consume living cells or dead organic matter. Fungus-like protists feed on bacteria or decaying vegetation. Option D. Protozoa – This option is incorrect because protozoa are eukaryotic protists with genetic material sequestered in a nucleus. Since the genetic material of protozoa is separated from the rest of the cell via a nuclear membrane, simultaneous transcription and translation cannot occur. Protozoa are unicellular, animal-like protists that are further classified by their method of movement. Protozoa are heterotrophs as they consume living cells or dead organic matter.
explanation.poe_text: (Not found)

question.text: Which molecule is the precursor for the androgens, estrogens, and progesterone molecules necessary for sexual development?

explanation.concept_text: Steroids are a category of hormones synthesized from cholesterol in the smooth ER. These hormones all retain the four-membered ring structure of cholesterol; however, differences in functional groups cause significant variations in functionality. Steroids include androgens, estrogens, progestogens, mineralocorticoids, and glucocorticoids. The former three steroids are collectively known as sex hormones . Examples include, respectively, testosterone, estradiol, and progesterone. These hormones are essential for sexual development as they are involved in processes including puberty, pregnancy, menstruation, sperm production, and more. The image below illustrates the sex hormone synthesis pathway from cholesterol. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Cytosine – This option is incorrect because cytosine is not used to synthesize hormones. As one of the five nucleotide bases, cytosine (C) is instead used to form DNA and RNA. The other three nucleotide bases in DNA are adenine (A), guanine (G), and thymine (T). In RNA, uracil (U) replaces thymine. The sequence of these nucleotide bases encodes genetic information in DNA and RNA. Option B. Glucose – This option is incorrect because glucose is a carbohydrate, and carbohydrates cannot be used to synthesize sex hormones. Lipids, specifically cholesterol, are used to synthesize sex hormones. Glucose can instead be used to make polysaccharides including starch, cellulose, and glycogen. Monosaccharides including glucose forms glycosidic linkages with one another to build polysaccharides. Glucose also fuels both aerobic and anaerobic respiration, allowing the production of energy. Option C. Tyrosine – This option is incorrect because tyrosine (an amino acid) can be used to synthesize amino-acid-derived hormones including melatonin, epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin. Sex hormones, however, are derived from cholesterol instead of amino acids. Option D. Polypeptide – This option is incorrect because polypeptide hormones are synthesized by ribosomes and are coded for in the genome. Such hormones include FSH, LH, ACTH, hGH, TSH, prolactin, ADH, PTH, glucagon, and insulin. Sex hormones, however, are derived from cholesterol instead of a polypeptide chain.

question.text: Which of the following is an example of coevolution?

explanation.concept_text: Coevolution is a process where two species influence one another’s evolution. Evolutionary pressures from one species cause the other one to evolve, and vice versa. Predators and prey commonly undergo coevolution. For example, the evolution of a more effective predator will cause the prey to evolve better ways to escape or defend itself. In turn, evolutionary advancements in the prey force the predator to evolve to keep up with the prey species. Coevolution is not always due to predator and prey relationships, however – it can be seen in any two species that share significant interactions and closely adapt to one another over time due to mutual benefits. The relationship between hummingbirds and trumpet creeper flowers is a popular example of coevolution. Hummingbirds have evolved long beaks to be able to drink from trumpet creeper flowers, which have particularly long, tubular petals. The trumpet creeper’s elongated shape is closely adapted for the long beak of the hummingbird, which is advantageous for the flower as matching the shape of the hummingbird’s beak means that its pollen will be spread to other compatible trumpet creeper flowers for successful pollination. In turn, the elongated shape of the hummingbird beak is advantageous for the hummingbird as it provides it efficient access to the nectar of the flower. The shared benefits ultimately drive the coevolution seen between these two species. Since hummingbirds and trumpet creeper flowers demonstrate coevolution in which reciprocal evolution has occurred, Option C is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Dolphin fin and fish fin – This option is incorrect because dolphin fins and fish fins do not demonstrate coevolution; instead, they are an example of analogous structures. Analogous structures are body parts of different species (which do not share a common ancestor) that closely resemble one another. While these structures have evolved independently, they have similar functions due to adaptations to similar environments. Dolphins and fish are different species that do not come from a common ancestor. However, since both species live in an aquatic habitat, their fins resemble one another in appearance and function. Option B. Antibiotics and bacteria – This option is incorrect because antibiotics and bacteria do not demonstrate coevolution; instead, they are an example of natural selection. Natural selection refers to the survival of the fittest. In a population experiencing natural selection, allele frequencies increase or decrease in order to adapt to the environment. When bacteria are exposed to antibiotics, “weaker” bacteria (those without genes for antibiotic resistance) will die quicker compared to “stronger” bacteria (those with the genes for antibiotic resistance). Hence, bacteria that are less susceptible to the antibiotic will survive and pass on their genes to succeeding generations. As a result, bacteria can develop resistance to antibiotics over time due to the resistant features that have been passed on through generations. Option D. Goats and cows – This option is incorrect because goats and cows are not an example of coevolution. Goats and cows are two different species that belong to the same family. However, these species do not share a significant evolutionary relationship and instead evolved independently from a common ancestor. Both are herbivores, and share adaptations for surviving on a vegetation-based diet, such as flat teeth and long digestive tracts. Option E. Human arm and cat leg – This option is incorrect because human arms and cat legs do not demonstrate coevolution; instead, they are an example of homologous structures resulting from divergent evolution. Homologous structures are similar body parts of different species that descended from a common ancestor. While homologous structures may or may not serve the same function, they share a physical resemblance. Since humans and cats share a common mammalian ancestor and the human arm and cat leg are similar in bone structure, human arms and cat legs are homologous structures.

question.text: Prokaryotic cells cannot grow beyond a small size due to which limitation?

options.label: A.
options.text: The metabolism of the prokaryotic organisms is too slow

options.label: B.
options.text: Nutrient exchange is insufficient at low surface area to volume ratios

options.label: C.
options.text: Prokaryotic membrane phospholipids are physically smaller than eukaryotic phospholipids

options.label: D.
options.text: Prokaryotic defenses only work against smaller organisms

options.label: E.
options.text: The nucleus to cytoplasm ratio would lead to an inability to produce sufficient gene products

correct_answer_text: Nutrient exchange is insufficient at low surface area to volume ratios

explanation.concept_text: Prokaryotic cells are significantly smaller than eukaryotic cells, usually ranging from 0.1 to 5.0 micrometers (μm). Prokaryotic cells cannot grow beyond this size range because of a limitation called the surface-area-to-volume ratio . As cells get larger in size, their volume grows much larger compared to their surface area. Hence, their surface-area-to-volume ratio gets smaller, making it harder for the cell to exchange nutrients and waste with the environment. If a cell is unable to efficiently exchange nutrients and waste with its environment, it will either begin cell division to increase surface area or die due to starvation and waste accumulation. Since a low surface area to volume ratio results in insufficient nutrient exchange, which limits prokaryotic cells from growing beyond a small size, Option B is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. The metabolism of the prokaryotic organisms is too slow – This option is incorrect because prokaryotic cells are not limited by their metabolism. Prokaryotes may perform aerobic or anaerobic respiration to acquire energy and carry out important cellular activities. Some prokaryotes have enzymes or special pathways that allow them to utilize compounds containing nitrogen or sulfur. Hence, prokaryotic organisms have their own efficient ways of metabolism that do not interfere with their growth. Option C. Prokaryotic membrane phospholipids are physically smaller than eukaryotic phospholipids – This option is incorrect because the size of membrane phospholipids does not differ between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Membrane phospholipids of both prokaryotes and eukaryotes are made up of the hydrophilic head and hydrophobic tail. The hydrophilic head includes the polar group, phosphate group, and glycerol, while the hydrophobic tail includes two fatty acids. The size of these components does not vary between prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Option D. Prokaryotic defenses only work against smaller organisms – This option is incorrect because the size of the prokaryote would not affect the ability of its immune system (which functions at a molecular level) to defend against pathogens. Option E. The nucleus to cytoplasm ratio would lead to an inability to produce sufficient gene products – This option is incorrect because while the nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio is important in controlling eukaryotic cell growth, prokaryotic cells lack a nucleus. Hence, prokaryotic cells cannot be affected by the nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio. Eukaryotes maintain an ideal nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio through mitosis.

question.text: How do decomposers play a role in the global carbon cycle?

options.label: A.
options.text: Decomposers perform respiration which provides carbon to plants for photosynthesis

options.label: B.
options.text: Decomposers incorporate carbon when they consume other organisms

options.label: C.
options.text: Decomposers’ dead body is left on soil for plant to absorb carbon

options.label: D.
options.text: Nitrogen fixing bacteria utilize their enzymes to convert nitrogen to carbon

options.label: E.
options.text: Decomposers do not participate in the carbon cycle

correct_answer_text: Decomposers perform respiration which provides carbon to plants for photosynthesis

explanation.concept_text: The carbon cycle describes the major reservoirs of carbon and the processes that drive the transport of carbon across those reservoirs. One of the major reservoirs of carbon is the atmosphere in the form of CO 2 . Atmospheric CO 2 is then absorbed by producers to carry out photosynthesis. Photosynthesis allows atmospheric CO 2 to be converted to organic forms that can be taken up by consumers and decomposers. After consuming carbon through food, consumers return carbon directly to the atmosphere through cellular respiration. Decomposers , also known as saprophytes , feed from dead, decaying matter by breaking the matter down through cellular respiration. Examples of decomposers include fungi and bacteria. These organisms secrete enzymes that can break down complex organic compounds into their components, which are then absorbed and broken down further in the process of cellular respiration. Hence, decomposers contribute to the carbon cycle as they help degrade organic matter into inorganic materials. The products of their cellular respiration include CO 2 , which is subsequently released into the atmosphere. Fossil fuel combustion is another source of atmospheric CO 2 . Fossil fuel combustion is the process of burning coal, oil, natural gases, or other fossil fuels to generate energy. Since decomposers make carbon available to plants in the form of CO 2 via cellular respiration, Option A is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Decomposers incorporate carbon when they consume other organisms – This option is incorrect because while decomposers do consume other organisms, they do not “incorporate” carbon into other organisms during consumption. Decomposers break down organic matter from dead organisms into simpler inorganic materials without the incorporation of additional carbon. Option C. Decomposers’ dead body is left on soil for plant to absorb carbon – This option is incorrect because decomposers break down dead organic material and waste and then convert it into carbon dioxide via respiration. While incomplete decomposition and fossilization can form fossil fuels that are eventually combusted into atmospheric carbon, plants do not play a role in this particular process. Plants receive carbon through the process of photosynthesis as they take in carbon dioxide and ultimately fix it into organic carbon sources such as glucose. Option D. Nitrogen fixing bacteria utilize their enzymes to convert nitrogen to carbon – This option is incorrect because nitrogen fixing bacteria utilize their enzymes to convert atmospheric nitrogen (N 2 – an inorganic form of nitrogen) into organic forms of nitrogen (e.g. NH 4 + ) that can be incorporated into organic molecules, instead of converting nitrogen to carbon. Nitrogen fixing bacteria play a key role in the nitrogen cycle, not the carbon cycle. Option E. Decomposers do not participate in the carbon cycle – This option is incorrect because decomposers participate in the global carbon cycle by breaking down organic matter from dead organisms into simpler inorganic materials through cellular respiration. The products of decomposition are then released into the atmosphere in the form of carbon dioxide, which can be used by plants in photosynthesis to continue the carbon cycle. The ability for decomposers to convert organic waste into inorganic carbon sources like carbon dioxide is a key component of the global carbon cycle.

question.text: Action potentials, motor end plate potentials, and muscle contraction all have what in common?

explanation.concept_text: Ion channels are used to pass ions across the membrane. These channels are also referred to as gated channels in nerve and muscle cells. Voltage gated ion channels are a type of ion channel that responds to differences in membrane potential. During nerve impulse transmission, a stimulus causes gated ion channels to open and Na + ions to enter the axon, depolarizing the neuron. Once the threshold level is reached, an action potential is triggered. The action potential causes the opening of voltage gated Na + channels down the entire length of the neuron. In response to the influx of Na + ions, voltage gated K + channels let K + ions out of the cell, resulting in repolarization of the neuron. Motor end plate potentials are the voltages that cause the depolarization of skeletal muscle fibers at the motor end plate (the area where nerve and muscle fiber interface). When an action potential arrives at the neuromuscular junction, acetylcholine is released. Acetylcholine then binds to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane that opens ligand gated Na + channels, which can eventually lead to sufficient voltage change to trigger the opening of voltage gated ion channels causing an action potential in the sarcolemma. As this action potential continues to travel along the T-tubules, the sarcoplasmic reticulum releases Ca 2+ through voltage gated Ca 2+ channels. This directly leads to muscle contraction, as the release of Ca 2+ prompts the formation of myosin cross bridges, resulting in Ca 2+ binding to troponin on an actin helix. The interactions between thick and thin filaments allow the sarcomere to shorten (a muscle contraction). At the end of each contraction cycle, Ca 2+ is actively pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Since action potentials, motor end plate potentials, and muscle contraction all require the activity of voltage gated ion channels, Option C is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Ligand gated ion channels – This option is incorrect because action potentials do not use ligand gated ion channels; therefore, ligand gated ion channels are not a common factor between all three processes mentioned in the question. Ligand gated ion channels are a type of ion channels that respond to the binding of neurotransmitters. While motor end plate potentials respond to the binding of acetylcholine to receptors on the postsynaptic membrane (eventually leading to muscle contraction), action potentials only use voltage gated ion channels. Option B. Mechanical gated ion channels – This option is incorrect because while mechanical gated ion channels are used to generate graded potentials, they are not directly used to generate action potentials, and play no role in motor end plates or muscle contraction. Mechanical gated ion channels respond to pressure or vibration and are found in sensory receptors in the skin, ear, etc. The graded potentials generated by these ion channels can surpass the threshold potential, subsequently triggering voltage gated ion channels to generate an action potential. While mechanical gated ion channels can indirectly trigger an action potential through the generation of graded potentials, they are not directly used to generate an action potential. Therefore, mechanical gated ion channels are not a common factor between all three processes mentioned in the question. Option D. cAMP – This option is incorrect because cAMP (cyclic AMP) is a secondary messenger used for intracellular signal transduction. Secondary messengers are molecules that relay signals received by cell-surface receptors. Since action potentials, motor end plate potentials, and muscle contraction are intercellular processes that occur between cells instead of inside a single cell, cAMP is not a common factor between all three processes mentioned in the question. Option E. Mitotic spindle – This option is incorrect because the mitotic spindle is not involved in action potentials, motor end plate potentials, and muscle contraction. The mitotic spindle is developed during prophase of mitosis and meiosis. The mitotic spindle attaches to chromosomes and later separates them by pulling them to opposite poles of the nucleus.

question.text: Which of the following lab techniques is most effective for evaluating the expression of multiple genes?

explanation.concept_text: DNA microarray is a multi-welled lab technique that allows for the simultaneous evaluation of the expression of multiple genes. Since the question is asking for the most effective technique for evaluating the expression of multiple genes and DNA microarray can simultaneously evaluate large groups of genes, Option B is correct. DNA microarray begins with sample isolation and preparation in which mRNA is isolated from cells. Once mRNA is isolated, it undergoes reverse transcriptase labeling for conversion into cDNA. mRNA must be converted to cDNA because cDNA is more convenient to work with: while mRNA is composed of both coding and noncoding sequences, cDNA only contains coding sequences. The cDNA is then placed in wells. Each well contains identical copies of cDNA fragments that each carry a specific gene. If a gene from the target DNA strand was expressed in a certain tissue, it binds to the cDNA inside the well; however, if a gene was not expressed, there would be no gene product to bind to the cDNA. Upon hybridization between cDNA segments and the target DNA strand, fluorescence occurs and can be measured via detectors, and the relative abundance of the target sequences can be shown in order to assess their expression. The image below illustrates the detailed steps of DNA microarray. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. PCR – This option is incorrect because PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a technique used to amplify the amount of DNA, having no impact on evaluating gene expression. PCR consists of three steps: denaturation, annealing, and elongation. Once high heat separates double stranded DNA, the sample is cooled to allow the attachment of primers onto the separated strands. Polymerase then synthesizes new strands of DNA. This cycle repeats to increase the amount of DNA exponentially. Option C. Karyotyping – This option is incorrect because karyotyping is a laboratory technique used to study the chromosomes of a cell. It involves the staining and photographing of chromosomes from a sample of cells in order to visually analyze the number and structure of the chromosomes. Karyotyping can be used to check for visually observable chromosomal abnormalities. For example, karyotyping can help diagnose Down Syndrome by identifying trisomy 21 (three chromosomes at position 21). While karyotyping can identify such chromosomal defects, it cannot be used to analyze gene expression in any way. Option D. Gel electrophoresis – This option is incorrect because gel electrophoresis is a technique used to separate and analyze DNA, RNA, or proteins based on their size and charge. Small molecules can travel relatively farther down the gel. After separating DNA samples, it can be sequenced or probed to locate specific sequences. While gel electrophoresis can only separate molecules based on size and charge, it cannot be used to evaluate gene expression. Option E. Western blot – This option is incorrect because Western Blot is a technique used to detect and quantify specific proteins in a sample. It involves the separation of proteins by size using gel electrophoresis, followed by the transfer of the separated proteins onto a nitrocellulose gel membrane. Once the proteins are transferred onto the membrane, a probe is added to hybridize and mark the target fragment. Western Blot can detect and quantify specific proteins in a sample, which can reflect whether or not individual genes are being expressed. However, Western blotting cannot be used to evaluate the expression of multiple genes simultaneously.

question.text: What effect do T3 (triiodothyronine) & T4 (thyroxine) have on the body?

explanation.concept_text: T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxine) are lipid soluble tyrosine derivative hormones produced by the thyroid. These hormones are necessary for growth and neurological development in children as well as increasing basal metabolic rate in the body. The basal metabolic rate is the amount of energy per unit of time that a person requires to keep the body functioning at rest. The undersecretion of these hormones causes hypothyroidism in which the heart rate, respiratory rate, and basal metabolic rate are lowered. On the other hand, the oversecretion of these hormones cause hyperthyroidism in which the basal metabolic rate and sweating are increased. Individuals suffering from hyperthyroidism notably tend to be very thin and have low levels of fat mass due to their excessively increased metabolism. Both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism can lead to formation of a goiter, the enlargement of the thyroid gland. It is important to know for the test that the element iodine is necessary for thyroid hormone synthesis. Since T3 and T4 both functions to increase metabolism (basal metabolic rate) in the body, Option B is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Increases muscle mass – This option is incorrect because thyroid hormones have no direct effect on skeletal muscle. Human growth hormone (GH) increases muscle mass. GH is produced by the anterior pituitary and is involved in height, bone, and muscle growth. Testosterone also contributes to an increase in muscle mass. Option C. Decreases gastric motility – This option is incorrect because while T3 and T4 are involved in maintaining gastric motility, the under secretion of these hormones would cause a decrease in gastric motility. Hence, patients with hypothyroidism frequently experience a decrease in gastric motility. Rather than decreasing gastric motility, T3 and T4 instead function to increase gastric motility (i.e. more frequent bowel movements). Option D. Stimulates T-cell development – This option is incorrect because thymosins stimulate T-cell development. Thymosins are proteins produced by the thymus that stimulate white blood cells to become T-cells that identify and destroy infected cells. T-cells originate in the bone marrow, but they mature in the thymus. It is important for the test to understand that the thymus – where T-cell development occurs – is completely independent in structure and function from the thyroid (where thyroid hormones are produced) despite a passing similarity in name. Option E. Regulates blood calcium – This option is incorrect because calcitonin and parathyroid hormone (PTH) are the hormones that regulate blood calcium levels. Calcitonin functions to lower blood calcium levels by stimulating osteoblast activity and suppressing osteoclast activity. Calcitonin also inhibits calcium from being released from the bone. On the other hand, PTH functions to increase blood calcium levels by stimulating calcium release from the bone. This calcium release increases osteocyte absorption of calcium from the bone and stimulates osteoclast activity. In contrast, the thyroid hormones have no role in regulation of blood calcium levels.

question.text: The development of structures in the appropriate segment along the head-tail axis is regulated by which of the following genes?

explanation.concept_text: Homeotic genes are genes that are involved in the structural development of body formation during the embryonic stages of organisms. HOX genes are a type of homeotic gene that is responsible for segmentation and placement of anatomic structures in an embryo, by turning on and off certain genes in certain segments of the body. This difference in gene expression affects which anatomic features develop in each segment. The homeobox sequence of the HOX genes is responsible for regulating anatomic features in the early stages of embryonic development. The image below shows the HOX genes involved in each segment of a fruit fly’s body. Small differences in HOX genes can alter the developmental process of related species. For example, while shrimps and grasshoppers are related species, they have very different physical structures caused by differences in HOX gene expression. Furthermore, mutations or deliberate manipulations to the HOX genes can cause certain anatomic structures to develop in the wrong segment of the body. For example, manipulated HOX genes can cause a leg to grow on the head of an organism. HOX genes tend to be highly conserved; hence, when these mutations occur, the organism often fails to develop properly. Since HOX genes control the development of structures in the appropriate segment along the head-tail axis, Option D is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. lacZ – This option is incorrect because the lac operon, of which lacZ is a part, does not regulate the development of anatomic structures along the head-tail axis. I lac operon is instead responsible for the metabolism of lactose in prokaryotes. lacZ, in particular, codes for B-galactosidase that converts lactose into glucose and galactose. The regulatory genes of the lac operon produce an active repressor that binds to the operator and blocks RNA polymerase. When lactose is available, lactose binds to the repressor and inactivates it, allowing RNA polymerase to transcribe the genes so lactose can be metabolized when it is present. Option B. p53 – This option is incorrect because the p53 gene does not regulate the development of anatomic structures along the head-tail axis. As one of the tumor suppressor genes, the p53 gene encodes for a protein responsible for tumor suppression in a cell. Since the p53 gene controls cell repair and apoptosis, the down regulation of the p53 gene can lead to its inability to stop normal cell growth, potentially leading to cancer. Option C. SRY – This option is incorrect because the SRY gene or sex-determining region Y gene does not regulate the development of anatomic structures along the head-tail axis. The SRY gene is instead responsible for the production of the testis-determining factor protein. This gene is found on the Y chromosome and is critical in male sexual organ development, particularly Sertoli cells which produce a signal that inhibits the formation of the Mullerian ducts: the embryonic structure that develops into the female reproductive tract. In the absence of the SRY gene, ovaries develop. Option E. trpE – This option is incorrect because the trp operon, of which trpE is a part, does not regulate the development of anatomic structures along the head-tail axis. The trp operon is instead responsible for tryptophan production in prokaryotes by producing enzymes for tryptophan synthesis. The regulatory genes of the trp operon produce an inactive repressor that allows RNA polymerase to ultimately produce tryptophan. When tryptophan is already available, tryptophan binds to the inactive repressor and activates it. The repressor then binds to the operator and blocks RNA polymerase from transcription, therefore preventing tryptophan synthesis.

question.text: In the given action potential graph, what does E represent?

options.label: D.
options.text: Efflux of potassium ions causing hyperpolarization

correct_answer_text: Efflux of potassium ions causing hyperpolarization

explanation.concept_text: The resting potential (-70mV) is the normal polarized state of the neuron. Once a stimulus causes gated ion channels to open and sodium ions to enter the axon, the neuron becomes depolarized. In the given graph, A represents a graded potential and B represents the depolarization of the neuron. If the threshold level (-50 to -55mV) is reached, an action potential is generated. This action potential results in the opening of voltage gated sodium ion channels down the entire length of the neuron. In the given graph, C represents the peak action potential of the neuron. At the peak action potential, voltage gated sodium ion channels close. In response to the significantly more positive membrane potential caused by the influx of sodium ions, more gated ion channels allow potassium ions to leave the cell, allowing the neuron to restore its resting state. This restoration of polarization is called repolarization and it is represented as D in the given graph. Following repolarization, voltage gated potassium ion channels are slow to close, causing too many potassium ions to be released from the cell and the membrane potential to drop. When there is such overcorrection of the membrane potential, the neuron is undergoing hyperpolarization , represented as E in the given graph. After hyperpolarization, the neuron goes through a refractory period in which the neuron will not respond to a new stimulus until sodium-potassium pumps return the ions and restore resting potential. The image below shows an action potential graph labelled with the stages of nerve impulse transmission. Since E represents hyperpolarization caused by the efflux of potassium ions, Option D is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Influx of sodium causing depolarization – This option is incorrect because B represents the influx of sodium ions causing depolarization. A neuron is depolarized when a stimulus causes gated ion channels to open and sodium ions to enter the axon. Hence, the membrane potential increases when depolarization occurs due to positively charged sodium ions entering the cell, until the neuron reaches peak action potential and the voltage gated sodium ion channels close. Option B. Activation of leaky potassium channels – This option is incorrect because leaky potassium channels are always open to help maintain resting potential; therefore, leaky potassium channels do not have to be activated to allow the flow of potassium ions. Resting potential is maintained by sodium-potassium pumps and leaky potassium channels. The sodium-potassium pumps, powered by ATP hydrolysis, let three sodium ions out and two potassium ions in. The leaky potassium channels let potassium ions out through passive ion leakage. Option C. Blocking of calcium channels – This option is incorrect because the blocking of calcium channels does not occur in nerve impulse transmission and therefore cannot be found in an action potential graph. The blocking of calcium channels can instead occur in transmission across chemical synapses. Depolarization leads to the opening of calcium channels and allows calcium ions to enter the cell. The influx of calcium ions causes the release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft. However, if calcium channels are blocked, calcium ions cannot enter the cell, preventing neurotransmitters from being released into the synaptic cleft. Option E. Acetylcholine recycling – This option is incorrect because acetylcholine recycling does not occur in nerve impulse transmission and therefore cannot be found in the given graph. Acetylcholine recycling instead occurs in transmission across chemical synapse. After acetylcholine molecules are released into the synaptic cleft, they are broken down by enzymes in the cleft for reuptake by the neurons. Acetylcholine is then broken down via the enzyme acetylcholinesterase in a hydrolysis reaction. The hydrolyzed products (choline and acetate) are reabsorbed and reused by the neurons.

question.text: Which of the following structures covers the lungs?

explanation.concept_text: Lungs are invaginated structures made of two sections: the left lung and the right lung. These structures have a membranous cover called the pleurae which has two pleura layers: the visceral pleura and the parietal pleura. The visceral pleura lines the surface of the lungs, while the parietal pleura lines the inside of the chest cavity. The pleura functions to protect and cushion the lungs.
