It also produces fluid that coats the pleura and acts as a lubricant between the lungs and the chest wall during breathing.  The space in between these two layers is called the intrapleural space. The intrapleural space has a lower pressure than the atmosphere. The pressure of the intrapleural space decreases as we inhale, since the lung cavity opens up and increases in volume during inhalation. Since the pleurae is a membranous cover that lines the lungs, Option B is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Alveoli – This option is incorrect because the alveoli do not cover the lungs; instead, they are small air sacs at the ends of bronchioles. Gas exchange between the circulatory system and the lungs occurs across capillaries wrapped around alveoli. The alveoli are coated with surfactant in order to reduce surface tension and prevent collapsing as we inhale and exhale. Option C. Cartilage – This option is incorrect because cartilage does not cover the lungs. Cartilage is an avascular connective tissue that can be found in the ear, nose, larynx, trachea, and joints. This soft and flexible tissue helps to reduce friction between bones and absorb shock in the joints. The trachea, specifically, contains C-shaped cartilage covered by cilia and mucus cells. This C-shaped cartilage provides structural support to the trachea and keeps the airway open. Option D. Gastrin – This option is incorrect because as a hormone of the digestive system, gastrin does not cover the surface of lungs. Gastrin is a peptide hormone secreted by G cells of the stomach. This hormone is absorbed into blood and stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl. HCl creates an acidic environment in the stomach which is essential for the activation of pepsinogen into pepsin, which subsequently digests proteins. Option E. Blood – This option is incorrect because blood does not cover the surface of lungs. While lungs contain air sacs that are surrounded by networks of capillaries, blood itself does not cover the surface of lungs. Blood is a type of connective tissue that consists of plasma (liquid), serum, erythrocytes (red blood cells), leukocytes (white blood cells), and thrombocytes (platelets). Blood mainly functions to transport gases (oxygen and carbon dioxide) and nutrients throughout the body.

question.text: A dog always follows commands from his owner (like sitting), but always expects a treat in return. This is due to __________.

explanation.concept_text: Classical conditioning occurs when an animal recognizes that events are connected. A well-known example of classical conditioning is Pavlov’s experiment. Dogs naturally salivate when presented with food. This salivation caused by food is called the unconditioned response as it is an innate reflex to an unconditioned stimulus —in this case, food. During his experiment, Pavlov rang a bell when food was presented. After some time, the dogs began to associate the sound of the bell with food. In the beginning of the experiment, ringing the bell without any food did not elicit a response in the dogs. However, at the end of the experiment, the dogs salivated at the sound of the bell without the presence of food. Therefore, the sound of the bell became a conditioned stimulus that caused a response even in the absence of the unconditioned stimulus. The salivation caused by the conditioned stimulus is called the conditioned response . In the situation presented in the question, a dog follows commands from his owner, expecting a treat in return. The treats, similar to the food used in Pavlov‘s experiment, are an unconditioned stimulus . The dog initially does not associate this unconditioned stimulus with the commands. However, after some time of training, the dog begins to associate the commands with the treats. The commands are now a conditioned stimulus that elicits a conditioned response from the dog—in this case, following of the command. Since a dog following commands to receive a treat is an example of classical conditioning, Option C is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Habituation – This option is incorrect because habituation is a learned behavior that allows individuals to ignore repetitive, inconsequential events. For example, anemones will not react to being repeatedly poked with a stick. Anemones usually react to contact because it may be food; however, after being repeatedly poked with a stick, anemones will learn that the stick is not food and perceive the event as inconsequential. Habituation does not explain the given behavior because in the question, the dog is not ignoring the commands of the owner. Option B. Sensitization – This option is incorrect because sensitization is an increased response to a repeated stimulus. Sensitization does not explain the given behavior because dogs do not show an increased response when their owners repeat the same commands. In this question, the dog shows the same response to the same command. Option D. Imprinting – This option is incorrect because imprinting is a rapid learning process in which young animals develop a long-lasting behavioral response to a specific individual or object. Imprinting is an innate behavior acquired during a critical/sensitive period of an organism, typically right after birth or hatching. An example of imprinting is when graylag goslings accept any moving object as their mother during their first day of life. Imprinting does not explain the given behavior because dogs following commands is a behavior acquired through training that does not necessarily happen during their early stages of life. Option E. Aposematic coloration – This option is incorrect because aposematic coloration is a conspicuous pattern or coloration of animals that warns predators that they should be avoided. For example, poisonous frogs have bright colors to warn predators of their toxicity. Aposematic coloration does not explain the given behavior because dogs following commands is a behavior that is completely unrelated to displayed warnings signs.

question.text: Which organism would be most affected if it were put in a solution with an enzyme that degraded chitin?

explanation.concept_text: Chitin is a beta-glucose polymer that functions as a structural molecule in fungal cell walls and arthropod exoskeletons. Thus, the correct answer will either belong to fungi or arthropods. Yeast falls under the category of unicellular fungi and has a cell wall that includes chitin, as shown in the image below. Therefore, if an enzyme were to degrade chitin, yeast would suffer the most damage because the enzyme will degrade its cell wall. Since the question is asking to identify the organism that would be most affected by the chitin-degrading enzyme, Option A is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Pine tree – This option is incorrect because pine trees belong to the plant kingdom that has cell walls made up of cellulose, not chitin. Chitin and cellulose are similar in structure (both being beta-glucose polymers); however, chitin has nitrogen-containing groups attached to each beta-glucose group unlike cellulose. Option C. Slime molds – This option is incorrect because slime molds are fungus-like protists that distinguish from fungi by NOT having chitin in their cell wall. While slime molds resemble fungi by forming filaments and spore-bearing bodies, their cell walls are made up of cellulose instead of chitin. There are two types of slime molds: cellular and plasmodial. While cellular slime molds reproduce asexually via mitosis, plasmodial slime mold cells fuse and form a diploid zygote. Option D. Diatoms – This option is incorrect because the cell walls of diatoms are made up of silica instead of chitin. Diatoms are plant-like protists that perform photosynthesis to obtain energy. Option E. Amoeba – This option is incorrect because amoeba do not have cell walls. Amoeba are animal-like protists that can move via pseudopods and are heterotrophic. They are known for consuming dead or dying organic matter for energy.

question.text: All of the following organisms are segmented EXCEPT for one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Segmentation refers to the division of body structures within organisms. Segmentation can be seen in arthropods, annelids, and chordates. Jellyfish belong to the animal phyla Cnidaria. Cnidarians do not possess body segmentation, differing from the other animals in the question. Cnidarians instead have two body forms: the floating, umbrella-shaped body with tentacles called the medusa and the immobile, cylinder-shaped body with rising tentacles called the polyp. Some cnidarians alternate between the medusa and polyp forms in their life cycle. The image below shows the life cycle of a jellyfish, including the asexual polyp stage and the sexual medusa stage. Since the question is asking to identify an organism that is not segmented and cnidarians, including jellyfish, do not possess body segmentation, Option E is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Earthworm – This option is incorrect because earthworms are a part of the animal phyla Annelida and therefore have segmented bodies which are repeated body units arranged along the anterior-posterior axis, each unit containing elements from a number of organ systems. Annelids also include leeches and polychaete worms. Option B. Dog – This option is incorrect because dogs are part of the animal phyla Chordata and have segmented bodies which are repeated body units arranged along the anterior-posterior axis, each unit containing elements from a number of organ systems. Dogs, in particular, belong to the subphyla Vertebrata and class Mammalia. Option C. Grasshopper – This option is incorrect because grasshoppers are part of the Phylum Arthropoda and therefore have segmented bodies which are repeated body units arranged along the anterior-posterior axis, each unit containing elements from a number of organ systems. Arthropods include spiders, insects, and crustaceans. Arthropods are characterized by their specialized body segments, jointed appendages, well-developed nervous systems, and exoskeletons made up of chitin. Option D. Lobster – This option is incorrect because lobsters are part of the class Crustacea of the animal phyla Arthropoda and have segmented bodies which are repeated body units arranged along the anterior-posterior axis, each unit containing elements from a number of organ systems. Aside from segmented bodies, crustaceans have gills with a variable number of appendages and two pairs of antennae. Crustaceans include crabs, shrimps, lobsters, crayfish, and barnacles.

question.text: Which of the structures below is analogous with a bird's wing?

explanation.concept_text: Analogous structures are body parts resulting from convergent evolution. In convergent evolution, species without a common ancestor evolved structures with similar functions as adaptations to similar environments, known as analogous structures. Homologous structures are body parts resulting from divergent evolution. In divergent evolution, species with a common ancestor develop into very different species. Structures that had a common ancestral relationship that may or may not still be similar in function are known as homologous structures. Bats are mammals, while birds are not. Therefore, bats and birds do not have a recent common ancestor. Nevertheless, they both have wings for the ability of flight which are an example of analogous structures. Since birds and bats descended from different ancestors but have structures (wings) that serve the same function of flying, Option D is correct. Canadian DAT Pro Tip : Although bird and bat wings are analogous, at the skeletal level, their forelimbs are homologous as shown in the images below. Birds and bats did not inherit wings from a common ancestor with wings, but they did inherit forelimbs from a common ancestor with forelimbs. This particular example is important to know for the test! CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Whale fin – This option is incorrect because the bird wing and whale fin are not analogous structures that result from convergent evolution. In convergent evolution, species without a common ancestor evolve similar structures as adaptations to similar environments. However, a whale fin provides a different function compared to a bird’s wing. Whale fins allow whales to steer and balance in water, while a bird’s wings allow birds to fly. Option B. Human arm – This option is incorrect because the bird wing and human arm are not analogous structures that result from convergent evolution. In convergent evolution, species without a common ancestor evolve similar structures as adaptations to similar environments. However, a human arm provides a different function compared to a bird’s wing. Human arms allow motility and the ability to reach out and grab objects, while a bird’s wings instead function for flight. Option C. Platypus beak – This option is incorrect because the bird wing and platypus beak are not analogous structures that result from convergent evolution. In convergent evolution, species without a common ancestor evolve similar structures as adaptations to similar environments. However, a platypus beak provides a different function compared to a bird’s wing. Platypus beaks allow platypus to find its way and search for prey, while a bird’s wings allow birds to fly. Option E. Bird leg – This option is incorrect because the bird wing and bird leg are not analogous structures that result from convergent evolution. In convergent evolution, species without a common ancestor evolve similar structures as adaptations to similar environments. However, since the bird leg and bird wing belong to the same species, they have a common ancestor, making it impossible for the structures to be products of convergent evolution.

question.text: What organelle is responsible for lipid synthesis?

explanation.concept_text: The smooth endoplasmic reticulum (smooth ER) is a continuous membrane system (composed of membrane-enclosed tubules and sacs) that lacks ribosomes. The smooth ER is responsible for lipid biosynthesis, production of steroid hormones for export, and detoxification. The rough ER, on the other hand, is studded with ribosomes and is responsible for folding, sorting, and transporting proteins synthesized by ribosomes. It is also capable of post-translational modification of proteins by adding various chemical groups to the protein structure. The shapes and locations of the smooth and rough ER are shown in the image below. Since the question is asking to identify the organelle that is responsible for lipid synthesis, Option B is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Lysosome – This option is incorrect because lysosomes do not synthesize lipids; they instead contain hydrolytic enzymes to digest biomolecules and function in apoptosis (controlled cell suicide). Lysosomes also help carry out autophagy by using their digestive enzymes to degrade the cell’s own components. In addition, phagocytotic white blood cells contain large amounts of lysosomes in order to break down consumed pathogens. Lysosomes are vesicles produced from the Golgi apparatus. Option C. Nucleolus – This option is incorrect because while the nucleolus is found inside the nucleus which is an organelle, the nucleolus itself is generally not considered an independent organelle, nor does it synthesize lipids; it is a region inside the eukaryotic nucleus that is involved in ribosome production. Ribosomes are synthesized using rRNA and ribosomal proteins imported from the cytoplasm. Once ribosomal subunits form within the nucleolus, they are exported to the cytoplasm for final assembly. Option D. Nucleoid – This option is incorrect because the nucleoid is not an organelle and does not synthesize lipids. The nucleoid is a region of high chromosome density within prokaryotic cells. The prokaryotic genome is stored in the nucleoid, as prokaryotes lack a nucleus. Option E. Vacuoles – This option is incorrect because vacuoles do not synthesize lipids; they are membrane-bound organelles involved in the storage or sequestration of molecules. Examples of vacuoles include transport vacuoles, food vacuoles, central vacuoles, storage vacuoles, and contractile vacuoles. While transport vacuoles and food vacuoles can be found in any eukaryotic cell, central vacuoles and storage vacuoles can only be found in plant cells. Contractile vacuoles are found in single-celled protists such as amoeba and paramecium to allow them to survive hypotonic environments. Vacuoles are distinguished from vesicles as they tend to be larger and less transient. While vacuoles store material, vesicles transport material and can fuse with target membranes to deposit their cargo.

question.text: A scientist submerges an unknown molecule in an aqueous solution and the molecule spontaneously forms a bilayer. What molecule would this be?

explanation.concept_text: Phospholipids are lipid molecules that consist of two fatty acids and one phosphate group joined to a glycerol backbone, as shown in the image below. The region with the two fatty acid tails is hydrophobic because this area consists entirely of nonpolar hydrocarbons. The other region is the hydrophilic head, consisting of the glycerol backbone and phosphate group. The ester linkage of the glycerol backbone and the negative charge of the phosphate group allow the hydrophilic head to interact with the polar water molecules in the aqueous solution. Since phospholipids have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions, they are amphipathic molecules. This amphipathic property means that a part of phospholipids (hydrophobic region) aims to aggregate together to avoid water, while the other part (hydrophilic region) spontaneously seeks to interact with water as much as possible. Hence, phospholipids are able to spontaneously form double-layered structures that consist of a hydrophobic interior layer and hydrophilic exterior layers. Since the question is asking to identify a molecule that can form a bilayer when placed in an aqueous solution, Option E is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Albumins – This option is incorrect because albumins do not spontaneously form a bilayer in aqueous solutions. Albumins are simple, functional proteins that act as carriers or enzymes in the blood. By using their water-soluble properties, albumins help transport substances (such as fatty acids, hormones, ions, and vitamins), and also helps to maintain the osmotic pressure of the blood. Option B. Cholesterols – This option is incorrect because while cholesterols are also amphipathic lipid molecules, their four relatively bulky rings prevent them from packing in the same manner as phospholipids to form bilayers. Nevertheless, cholesterol plays an important role in the bilayer of cell membranes by maintaining membrane fluidity. Cell membranes are required to maintain a certain degree of fluidity and are capable of changing membrane fatty acid composition and incorporating cholesterol to do so. In cold weather, cell membranes become more rigid. To prevent the membrane from becoming too rigid, cholesterol is incorporated into the membrane to increase fluidity by helping prevent the phospholipids from packing together too tightly. In warm weather, cell membranes become more fluid. To prevent the membrane from collapsing due to excessive flexibility, cholesterol is added into the membrane to restrict fatty acid movement. Option C. Proteoglycans – This option is incorrect because proteoglycans do not spontaneously form a bilayer in aqueous solutions. Proteoglycans are heavily glycosylated proteins. In other words, they are proteins with attached carbohydrate groups. Depending on their type and structure, they may or may not have hydrophobic components. While some membrane proteoglycans have hydrophobic regions that span cell membranes, other proteoglycans lack a hydrophobic region. Furthermore, even if the proteoglycan is amphipathic, their relatively bulky size prevents them from packing in the same manner as phospholipids to form bilayers. Option D. Triglycerides – This option is incorrect because triglycerides do not spontaneously form a bilayer in aqueous solutions. While triglycerides are also lipid molecules, they lack a polar phosphate group and instead have a total of three fatty acid tails attached to a glycerol backbone. As triglycerides have three very hydrophobic fatty acid tails and lack the negative charge of a phosphate group, they are considered hydrophobic.

question.text: In the pedigree chart below, what is the most likely form of genetic inheritance pattern?

explanation.concept_text: To determine the inheritance pattern, we first need to identify whether the trait is dominant or recessive. The trait is dominant if one of the parents has the trait and the trait does NOT skip a generation. An indication of a recessive inheritance pattern is when two unaffected parents have an affected child. Two unaffected parents can have an affected child when they are both carriers of the affected allele (heterozygous) and they both pass down the affected allele to their child. Since 8 and 9 are both unaffected but have an affected child (17), we can know that the inheritance pattern is recessive. We can further confirm that the inheritance pattern is not dominant because of the “skipped generation”: Individual 1 is affected, none of his children are, but one of his grandchildren is affected. We then need to identify whether the chart displays an autosomal or sex-linked trait. In autosomal traits, males and females are likely to be affected in equal proportions because males and females have the same number of autosomes. On the other hand, males are more commonly affected by X-linked recessive traits because males only have one X chromosome, while females have two. Since males only have one X chromosome, there is no paired chromosome to offset the effect of the affected chromosome. Furthermore, Y-linked traits never occur in females because females lack a Y chromosome. However, gender ratio alone is not sufficient to confirm whether the condition is sex-linked. Remember that in X-linked recessive conditions, an affected mother will only have sons who are affected (because both the mother’s X chromosomes are affected for her to have the condition, the son must inherit and express one of his mother’s affected X chromosome). In this pedigree chart, an affected mother (4) has an unaffected son (9) so we know this condition cannot be X-linked recessive. Since the inheritance pattern is recessive and autosomal, Option D is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. X-linked recessive – This option is incorrect because X-linked recessive traits tend to show up in males more often than females, which is not seen in the given pedigree chart. Males are more prone to X-linked recessive traits because they only need to inherit one faulty chromosome to have the condition, as their second chromosome is a Y chromosome. If a male inherits an affected X chromosome from his mother, there is no paired chromosome to offset the effect of the affected chromosome. In addition to gender ratio, if the trait were to be X-linked recessive, an affected mother should only have sons that are affected. However, in the given pedigree chart, an affected mother (4) has an unaffected son (9); therefore, the condition cannot be X-linked recessive. Option B. X-linked dominant – This option is incorrect because if the trait were to be X-linked dominant, all daughters of an affected father will be affected. All daughters of an affected father will be affected because females inherit one X chromosome from their father and in this case, that chromosome will be an affected chromosome. Due to the dominant nature of the condition, the daughter would always have the condition. However, in the given pedigree chart, an affected father (1) gave birth to unaffected daughters (7, 8); therefore, the condition cannot be X-linked dominant. Option C. Autosomal dominant – This option is incorrect because autosomal dominant traits do not skip a generation if one parent is affected. In the given pedigree chart, while 1 is affected by the trait, none of his children (6, 7, 8) are affected. If the trait were to be autosomal dominant, individuals 6, 7, and 8 would not have affected offspring of their own because autosomal dominant conditions do not “skip” a generation. However, individual 6 has an affected child (13) and individual 8 has an affected child (17); therefore, the condition cannot be autosomal dominant. Option E. Y-linked – This option is incorrect because there are affected females in the given pedigree chart. Only males are affected by Y-linked traits because females lack a Y chromosome.

question.text: If a cell was lysed and the contents were spun out in a centrifuge, rank the organelles from the order of lightest to heaviest:

options.label: E.
options.text: Organelles would not separate during centrifugation

explanation.concept_text: Centrifugation is a common technique used to prepare a sample for observation or further experimentation. Prior to centrifugation, the cells in a sample must be lysed. In other words, the membranes of the cells are broken open so that the contents of the cell are freely floating in a solution. Then, during centrifugation, the liquified sample is placed in a centrifuge which spins and separates the sample into layers based on density. During cell centrifugation, the liquified cell separates into layers containing different components of the cell. The order in which the cell components separate is based on density. The densest component spins out into a solid pellet layer at the bottom of the tube first, while the least dense component separates last. The order of separation is shown in the image below. The first layer to separate contains the nuclei. The next layer contains mitochondria and chloroplasts. The next layer contains microsomes and small vesicles. The final layer contains ribosomes, viruses, and larger macromolecules. In this sequence, after a round of centrifugation, the solid pellet layer is removed from the remaining non-pellet portion. The non-pellet portion is then spun again for further separation. In other words, each round of centrifugation separates out a different layer of organelles. Since the question is asking to rank the organelles from the order of lightest to heaviest (in other words, order of last to first to separate), Option B is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Mitochondria < Ribosomes < Nucleus – This option is incorrect because mitochondria are heavier than ribosomes. Hence, mitochondria separate earlier than ribosomes during centrifugation. The correct order would be Ribosomes < Mitochondria < Nucleus . Option C. Ribosomes < Nucleus < Chloroplast – This option is incorrect because nuclei are heavier than chloroplasts. Hence, nuclei separate earlier than chloroplasts during centrifugation. The correct order would be Ribosomes < Chloroplast < Nucleus . Option D. Nucleus < Mitochondria < Ribosomes – This option is incorrect because ribosomes are the lightest organelle and nuclei are the heaviest organelle. Hence, nuclei separate first and ribosomes separate last during centrifugation. The correct order would be Ribosomes < Mitochondria < Nucleus . Option E. Organelles would not separate during centrifugation – This option is incorrect because the components of a cell separate during centrifugation. Centrifugation spins and separates liquified cell homogenates into layers based on density.

question.text: A segment of DNA reads as follows: 5’ – ATATATGCGCACGC – 3’ What is the corresponding mRNA synthesized?

explanation.concept_text: Transcription is a process in which RNA molecules are synthesized from a DNA template in the nucleus. During transcription, RNA polymerase reads the template DNA strand in the 3′→5′ direction, but the mRNA is synthesized in the 5′→3′ direction. Furthermore, in RNA, there is no thymine (T) nucleotide. Instead, the nucleotide uracil (U) is used in its place. Uracil is energetically less expensive to produce than thymine, accounting for its use in RNA. The given segment of DNA reads as 5’ – ATATATGCGCACGC – 3’. Since RNA polymerase reads the template strand in the 3′→5′ direction, but the mRNA is formed in the 5′→3′ direction, the mRNA product should read as 3 ’ – UAUAUACGCGUGCG – 5 ’ . Since rewriting the mRNA product in the 5′→3′ direction reads as 5’ – GCGUGCGCAUAUAU – 3’ , Option B is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 5’-TATATACGCGTGCG-3’ – This option is incorrect because mRNA does not contain thymine (T), as thymine (T) is replaced with uracil (U) in mRNA. Therefore, it is impossible for this to be a strand of RNA transcribed from the template DNA given in the question. Option C. 3’-GCGUGCGCAUAUAU-5’ – This option is incorrect because mRNA is synthesized from 5’ to 3’ and the parent strand is read from 3’ to 5’. Therefore, when we read the parent strand in the question starting from the 3’ end and build the corresponding mRNA strand starting from the 5’ end, we get 5’-GCGUGCGCAUAUAU-3’ instead of 3’-GCGUGCGCAUAUAU-5’. In order for 3’-GCGUGCGCAUAUAU-5’ to be synthesized as the mRNA transcript, the given DNA strand would have to be 5’-CGCACGACTATATA-3’ as shown in the image below. Option D. 3’-GCCTGCGCATATAT-5’ – This option is incorrect because mRNA does not contain thymine (T), as thymine (T) is replaced with uracil (U) in mRNA. Therefore, it is impossible for this to be a strand of RNA transcribed from the template DNA given in the question. Option E. 3’-ATATATGGGCACGC-5’ – This option is incorrect because mRNA does not contain thymine (T), as thymine (T) is replaced with uracil (U) in mRNA. Therefore, it is impossible for this to be a strand of RNA transcribed from the template DNA given in the question.

question.text: Two species of monkeys emerge from a common ancestor. They live in the same jungle and are hunted by the same predators. Both species of monkeys have evolved prehensile tails and increased upper arm strength. Despite their similarities, they are not capable of interbreeding. Which form of evolution has taken place?

explanation.concept_text: The figure below depicts three forms of evolution: divergent, parallel, and convergent. Note that divergent and parallel evolution are similar in that two species come from a common ancestor. Since the two species of monkeys emerged from a common ancestor, either divergent or parallel evolution has taken place. As mentioned in the question, the two species of monkeys evolved similar features (prehensile tails and increased upper arm strength). Hence, we can infer that the species went through parallel evolution in which they made similar evolutionary changes after their divergence from a common ancestor. Since the two species of monkeys underwent parallel evolution in which they share a common ancestor and possess similar evolutionary features, Option E is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Convergent – This option is incorrect because convergent evolution occurs when two unrelated species that do not share a common ancestor evolve to share similar traits. Since the two species of monkeys emerged from a common ancestor and therefore are related, convergent evolution could not have taken place. An example of convergent evolution is the relationship between insect and bat wings. While insect and bat wing share functional similarities (function of flight), insects and bats do not share a common ancestor. Option B. Divergent – This option is incorrect because divergent evolution occurs when two related species become increasingly different over time as a result of speciation. While the two species of monkeys did split from a common ancestor, they did not become increasingly different over time. In fact, the two species of monkeys continued to evolve similar features including prehensile tails and increased upper arm strength. An example of divergent evolution are the finches of the Galapagos. The beak of the ancestral species of finches evolved over time to adapt to different food sources. Hence, beak shape and size now vary among finch species. Option C. Analogous – This option is incorrect because analogous evolution refers to the development of analogous structures, which are body parts that resemble one another between unrelated species due to adaptations to similar environments (e.g., bat wings vs. bee wings). Since the two species of monkeys emerged from a common ancestor, ‘analogous evolution’ could not have taken place. Option D. Coevolution – This option is incorrect because coevolution is an evolutionary relationship between two species in which one species causes the other one to evolve and vice versa. Hence, coevolution results in the evolution of both species. Since the two species of monkeys did not cause each other to evolve, coevolution did not take place. An example of coevolution is the relationship between predators and prey. The evolution of a more effective predator causes the prey to evolve better ways to defend itself. Similarly, the evolution of a more effective prey causes the predator to evolve better ways to capture the prey.

question.text: Which chamber of the heart directly pumps the highest concentration of oxygenated blood for distribution to the rest of the body?

explanation.concept_text: The heart is a muscular organ that uses strong contractions to propel blood throughout the circulatory system. The heart is composed of two separate pumps that contract simultaneously. The right side of the heart pumps blood to the lungs, while the left side of the heart pumps blood to the rest of the body. The heart has four chambers: the left and right atria (receiving chambers), plus the left and right ventricles (pumping chambers). The atrioventricular and semilunar valves prevent the backward flow of blood into the atria and ventricles, respectively. Blood flows through the circulatory system as follows: The image below shows the pulmonary and systemic flow of blood through the circulatory system. As shown in the image below, oxygenated blood is pumped to the body by the left ventricle. Since the left ventricle is a chamber that has the highest concentration of oxygenated blood for distribution to the rest of the body, Option A is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Right ventricle – This option is incorrect because the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood toward the lungs and therefore will not have the highest concentration of oxygenated blood (in fact, the right ventricle carries blood that is very deoxygenated). The right ventricle pumps the deoxygenated blood into the pulmonary artery through the pulmonary semilunar valve. Option C. Left atrium – This option is incorrect because while the left atrium has a high concentration of oxygenated blood, it simply acts as a holding chamber for blood returning from the lungs via the pulmonary veins. The left ventricle is the chamber that directly pumps the highest concentration of oxygenated blood to the rest of the body. Option D. Right atrium – This option is incorrect because the right atrium acts as a holding chamber for deoxygenated blood returning from the body and therefore will not have the highest concentration of oxygenated blood. Deoxygenated blood enters the right atrium via the superior and inferior vena cava. The blood kept inside the right atrium is pumped to the right ventricle through the atrioventricular/tricuspid valve.

question.text: Which of the following characteristics would be seen in an inefficient respiratory system?

explanation.concept_text: Arthropods , including most insects and mollusks, have an open circulatory system. The open circulatory system pumps blood into an internal cavity called the hemocoel , which soaks tissues in a bath of hemolymph . The hemolymph contains oxygen and nutrients necessary for the functioning of organs. The hemolymph eventually returns to the pumping mechanism through holes called ostia. On the other hand, the closed circulatory system transports blood via arteries, veins, and capillaries. The open circulatory system is inefficient compared to the closed circulatory system for numerous reasons. Closed circulatory systems have more directed blood flow and a higher blood pressure, allowing a faster flow of blood. Furthermore, unlike open circulatory systems, most closed circulatory systems separate oxygen-rich and oxygen-poor blood. By isolating oxygenated blood, oxygen can be transported faster to tissues without being “contaminated” by deoxygenated blood that lacks oxygen. The blood in closed circulatory systems also has a higher carrying capacity for oxygen, allowing larger amounts of oxygen to be bound to hemoglobin and transported throughout the body. Therefore, closed circulatory systems can transport oxygen faster and allow a more efficient respiratory system. Since the open circulatory system contributes to slower oxygen transport and inefficient gas exchange, Option C is correct.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Increased alveoli – This option is incorrect because increased alveoli can be found in efficient respiratory systems. Alveoli are small air sacs that allow gas exchange between the circulatory system and the lungs. Since alveoli are sites of gas exchange, increasing the number of alveoli will lead to more efficient respiration as there is increased surface area for gas exchange and more sites for oxygen to enter the blood and carbon dioxide to leave. Option B. Moist skin – This option is incorrect because moist skin can be found in efficient respiratory systems. Annelids secrete mucus to create a moist surface for gas exchange via diffusion. Some arthropods, including grasshoppers, have moistened tracheal endings to ease the rate of diffusion. Since gases including oxygen and carbon dioxide dissolve more easily in water, the moisture keeps the skin permeable and facilitates the absorption of these gases into the skin. Option D. Feathery gills – This option is incorrect because feathery gills can be found in efficient respiratory systems. “Feathery” gills provide a large surface area for gas exchange to occur. This feature is particularly important for aquatic organisms because water contains extremely low levels of dissolved oxygen. Hence, it is important for aquatic organisms to maximize the surface area of their respiratory systems. Don’t be thrown off by the use of the word “feathery” in this answer choice – feathery is simply a term used to describe the appearance of the gills in some fish, and should not be confused with actual feathers.

question.text: Tracheids are specialized plant cells that function to ___________.

explanation.concept_text: A plant is made up of many different parts. The three main parts are the roots, the leaves, and the stem. The structure of plant roots, leaves, and stems facilitates the transport of water and nutrients throughout the plant. The phloem and xylem are the main vascular tissues responsible for this movement. The phloem transports sugar, while the xylem transports water and minerals. As shown in the image below, t he xylem is composed of two types of cells: tracheids and vessel elements. Tracheids are elongated cells with tapered ends. They allow water and minerals to pass laterally by moving between openings in their walls from one tracheid cell to the next. Tracheids also provide structural support to the plant. Vessel elements are shorter and wider cells that combine to form a column called a vessel. Vessels have perforations that allow water to pass through vertically from one vessel element to another. Since tracheids are xylem cells that function to transport water and minerals throughout a plant, Option B is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Photosynthesize – This option is incorrect because chloroplasts are involved in photosynthesis, not tracheids. Chloroplasts are organelles unique to plant cells that produce energy through photosynthesis. Photosynthesis is the process by which carbon dioxide and water are converted into glucose and oxygen. Chlorophyll, the green pigment inside chloroplasts, captures light energy from sunlight in order to carry out photosynthesis. Option C. Transport sugars – This option is incorrect because the phloem is involved in transporting sugars and other organic nutrients. The phloem is made of cells called sieve-tube members that form fluid-conducting columns called sieve tubes. These cells lack nuclei and ribosomes. Sieve tubes are associated with companion cells that supply sugar to the phloem. These sieve tubes are connected to one another by plasmodesmata to maintain structure. Option D. Absorb water – This option is incorrect because tracheids are involved in the transport of water, not absorption. Roots, specifically root hair cells, are responsible for the absorption of water and minerals from the soil. In addition to absorbing water and minerals, roots function to anchor the plant into the soil. Vascular plants (tracheophytes) have true roots, while nonvascular plants such as bryophytes do not. Option E. Absorb energy from the sun – This option is incorrect because molecules of light-absorbing pigments called chlorophyll contained in the chloroplasts absorb energy in the form of light from the sun. Light is then incorporated into electrons, causing them to be excited and lose stability. These excited electrons re-emit the absorbed energy which is then reabsorbed by electrons in adjacent pigment molecules.

question.text: Which of the following was the important organic molecule formed by the Miller-Urey experiment?

explanation.concept_text: The Miller–Urey experiment was a chemical experiment that simulated the conditions of the primordial, early Earth and tested the chemical origin of life under those conditions. The image below shows the setup of the experiment that utilized a closed system. American chemists Harold Urey and Stanley Miller combined warm water with water vapor, methane, ammonia, and molecular hydrogen. This gaseous mixture was then pulsed with high-voltage electrical discharges. These components were meant to simulate the primitive ocean, heat, lightning, and the prebiotic atmosphere. Miller and Urey collected the products of the experiment in liquid form by using a condenser. A week later, they found that simple organic molecules such as amino acids had formed. In addition to amino acids, they found several fatty acids, carbon monoxide, and aldehydes as well. Thus, the Miller-Urey experiment successfully produced organic molecules from inorganic components thought to have been present on the prebiotic Earth. Since amino acids were an important organic molecule synthesized during the Miller-Urey experiment, Option E is correct. CC BY 4.0
explanation.poe_text: ption A. RNA – This option is incorrect because RNA was not a product of the Miller-Urey experiment that simulated the conditions thought to be present on early Earth. RNA (ribonucleic acid) is a single-stranded nucleic acid that is made up of nitrogenous bases attached to ribose sugars. Option B. Glycogen – This option is incorrect because glycogen was not a product of the Miller-Urey experiment that simulated the conditions thought to be present on early Earth. Glycogen is an α-glucose polymer that stores energy in animal cells. Option C. DNA – This option is incorrect because DNA was not a product of the Miller-Urey experiment that simulated the conditions thought to be present on early Earth. DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) is a double-stranded nucleic acid that is made up of nitrogenous bases attached to deoxyribose sugars. Option D. ATP – This option is incorrect because ATP was not a product of the Miller-Urey experiment that simulated the conditions thought to be present on early Earth. ATP (adenosine triphosphate) is a source of energy at the cellular level. It stores its potential energy in the form of chemical energy. ATP is produced in the mitochondria through a process called phosphorylation. Phosphorylation is the process in which ADP (adenosine diphosphate) combines with phosphate to form ATP.
